facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 381 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 381 of 1967. Appeal from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated June 30, 1966, July 4, 1966 and July 5, 1966 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 111 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated June 30, 1966, July 4, 1966 and,, July 5, 1966 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 1 1 1 of 1963.

facts.text: High Court at Bombay reversing the judgment of the learned Single Judge dated 29 October, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment dated 30 June, 1966 and 4 and 5 July, 1966 of the High Court at Bombay reversing the judgment of the learned Single Judge dated 29 October, 1963.

facts.text: The order of the Government of Bombay dated 8 May, 1962 repatriating the appellant from the temporary post of Controller of Foodgrains Department, Bombay to his parent Department of Excise and Prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: The only question in this appeal is whether the order of the Government of Bombay dated 8 May, 1962 repatriating the appellant from the temporary post of Controller of Foodgrains Department, Bombay to his parent Department of Excise and Prohibition amounted to a reduction in rank

facts.text: Appellant joined service as Sub-Inspector of Excise in the Excise and Prohibition Department of the Government of Bombay in the year 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant joined service as Sub-Inspector of Excise in the Excise and Prohibition Department of the Government of Bombay in the year 1938. He was thereafter selected for transfer to the Bombay City Police Department.

facts.text: In 1942 he was sent on deputation to the Civil Supplies Department as an Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: He was thereafter selected for transfer to the Bombay City Police Department. In 1942 he was sent on deputation to the Civil Supplies Department as an Inspector. He continued to work in that department up to the month of February, 1955.

facts.text: By February, 1955 he had become Rationing Officer which was a gazetted post and drawing a salary of Rs. 530 p.m. in the grade of Rs. 350-20-550.

anchor.surface_text: He continued to work in that department up to the month of February, 1955. By February, 1955 he had by various promotions become Rationing Officer which was a gazetted post and he was then drawing a salary of Rs. 530 p. m. in the grade of Rs. 350-20-550.

facts.text: In 1955 there was decontrol of foodgrains. The post was abolished. The appellant was reverted to the Excise Department.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955 there was decontrol of foodgrains. The post was abolished. The appellant was reverted to the Excise Department. In course of time he was promoted to the post of District Inspector in the Excise Department

facts.text: In 1957, the appellant was asked to go on deputation in the Agriculture and Forests Department as a Sub-Inspector under the Controller of Foodgrains Distribution, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: In 1957, the Government of Bombay again introduced the system of distribution of foodgrains on the basis of household cards. The appellant in view of his record of service in the Civil Supplies Department was asked to go on deputation

facts.text: In 1960, the appellant was appointed to a temporary post of Controller of Foodgrains Distribution, Bombay in the grade of Rs. 475-25-600-50-750.

anchor.surface_text: In 1960, the appellant was appointed to a temporary post of Controller of Foodgrains Distribution, Bombay in the grade of Rs. 475-25-600-50-750. In 1961 the appellant was drawing a salary of Rs. 500 p. m. as a Controller of Foodgrains Distribution.

facts.text: The appellant married his daughter in the month of December 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant married his daughter in the month of December 1961. The appellants daughter, a qualified doctor, was then working as a Resident Medical Officer in the Bombay Municipal Corporation.

facts.text: In months of January to March, 1962, Director of Civil Supplies asked appellant whether he had forced peons to do menial work at marriage, taken cash and gifts from Fair Price Shop-owners, forced staff to contribute cash for marriage.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was asked by the Director of Civil Supplies in the months of January to March, 1962 partly in writing and partly orally first whether he had forced his peons to do menial work at the marriage of his daughter, secondly, it ,he had taken cash and gifts from Fair Price Shop-owners and, thirdly, whether he had forced the staff to contribute in cash for the marriage of his daughter.

facts.text: The appellant denied these allegations.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied these allegations.

facts.text: In April 1962, Secretary to Government of Maharashtra, Agriculture and Forests Department told appellant there were complaints and no smoke without fire, would be repatriated.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Secretary to the Government of Maharashtra, Agriculture and Forests Department told the appellant in the month of April, 1962 that there were complaints against him and that there could be no smoke without fire, and the appellant would be repatriated to the Prohibition and Excise Department.

facts.text: In April 1962, Minister of Civil Supplies visited appellant's office and said there were complaints.

anchor.surface_text: The Minister of Civil Supplies in the month of April, 1962 visited the appellants office and said that there were complaints against him.

facts.text: Appellant requested a thorough enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant requested a thorough enquiry in connection with such complaints.

facts.text: Inspector of Police of Anti-corruption Branch took possession of several files of fair price shop-keepers.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to the visit of the Minister, an Inspector of Police of the Anti-corruption Branch took possession of several files of various fair price shop-keepers for scrutiny.

facts.text: Government of Bombay by resolution dated 8 May 1962 directed repatriation to parent department with immediate effect.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Government of Bombay by a resolution dated 8 May, 1962 directed that the appellant who was on deputation from the Excise and Prohibition Department should be repatriated to his parent department with immediate effect.

facts.text: Appellant posted as Officiating Inspector in Excise Department.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was asked to hand over charge and the appellant was posted by the Director of Excise and Prohibition in the Office of Officiating Inspector in his Department.

facts.text: In July 1962, appellant learnt Anti-corruption Branch report exonerated him from all charges.

anchor.surface_text: In the month of July, 1962 the appellant came to know that the Anti-corruption Branch of the Police submitted a report to the Government and the appellant was found to be exonerated from all charges.

facts.text: Learned Single Judge held order of 8 May 1962 was act of punishment and reduction in rank.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge of the Bombay High Court held that the order of 8 May, 1962 was an act of punishment and reduc- tion in rank.

facts.text: Division Bench reversed, held no legal right to post, reversion not punishment.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench of the Bombay High Court reversed that judgment and held that the appellant had no legal right to the post in the Department of Agriculture and Forests, and therefore his reversion was not a punishment.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside Division Bench, restores Single Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed. The Bench decision of the Bombay High Court is set aside and the judgment of the learned Single Judge is restored. The appellant will be entitled to costs in this Court.

facts.text: Court finds order of reversion was in nature of punishment, violation of Article 311.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the facts and circumstances to which reference has already been made bring out in bold relief that the order of reversion was in the nature of punishment. The order was not in compliance with the provisions of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant made representation to Government after exoneration, no reply.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made a representation to the Government bringing the said fact to the notice of the relevant authorities and requested for appointment to the post of Controller of Foodgrains. The Government did not send him any reply to the appellants representation.
This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment dated 30 June, 1966 and 4 and 5 July, 1966 of the High Court at Bombay reversing the judgment of the learned Single Judge dated 29 October, 1963.
amounted to a reduction in rank in violation of the provisions contained in Article 311 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: Article 311 makes no distinction between permanent and temporary members of the services or between persons holding permanent or temporary posts and affords protection to both classes of servants

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India, first proposition laid down by this Court

holdings.text: if a Government servant has no right to the particular rank his reduction from an officiating higher rank to his substantive lower rank will not by itself be a punishment

anchor.surface_text: secondly, if a Government servant has no right to the particular rank his reduction from an officiating higher rank to his substantive lower rank will not by itself be a punishment and, thirdly,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India, second proposition

holdings.text: the mere fact that the servant has no title to the post or the rank and the Government has by contract, express or implied or under the rules governing the conditions of his service, the right to reduce him to a lower post does not mean that the order of reduction of a servant to a lower post or rank cannot in any circumstance be a punishment

anchor.surface_text: thirdly, the mere fact that the servant has no title to the post or the rank and the Government has by contract, express or implied or under the rules governing the conditions of his service, the right to reduce him to a lower post does not mean that the order of reduction of a servant to a lower post or rank cannot in any circumstance be a punishment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India, third proposition

holdings.text: though the Government has right to revert a Government servant from the temporary post to a substantive post, the matter has to be viewed as one of substance and all relevant factors are to be considered in ascertaining whether the order is a genuine one of accident of service ... or whether the order amounts to a reduction in rank by way of punishment
holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance over form; consider all factors like aspersions on character despite lien and temporary nature

holdings.text: if there is evidence that the order of reversion is not a pure accident of service but an order in the nature of punishment, Article 311 will be attracted
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence-based determination distinguishes routine reversion from punitive

precedents.citation: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India  1

anchor.surface_text: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India  1 laid down three propositions First, Article 311 makes nodistinction between permanent and temporary members of the services or between persons holding permanent or temporary posts and affords protection to both classes of servants secondly,

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Article 311 makes no distinction between permanent and temporary servants; reversion from higher officiating rank not punishment per se if no right to post; but can be punishment if entails forfeiture of pay/allowances, loss of seniority, stoppage of promotion, or passed by way of penalty
precedents.cited_holding: laid down three propositions and two tests for determining if reduction is punishment

anchor.surface_text: Dhingras 1 case laid down two tests first, whether the servant had right to the post or the rank, or, secondly, whether he has been visited with evil consequences of the kind, mentioned in that decision.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: two tests to determine if reduction is punishment: right to the post or rank, or visited with evil consequences like forfeiture of pay, loss of seniority, etc.

precedents.citation: Sukhbans Singh v. State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: Sukhbans Singh v. State of Punjab 1  in dealing with the question as to whether a probationer has any right to hold the post said that it would not be correct to say that a probationer has a right to the higher post

precedents.case_name: Sukhbans Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: probationer has no right to higher post but cannot be reverted/punished for misconduct without complying with Article 311; on facts reversion was by way of punishment
precedents.cited_holding: reversion of probationer was punishment without compliance of Art 311, unsustainable

precedents.citation: Appar Apar Singh v. The State of Punjab Ors.0

anchor.surface_text: Appar Apar Singh v. The State of Punjab Ors.0 the question for consideration was whether an order reverting the appellant in that case from a post in Class I service in which he was officiating to his substantive post in Class II amounted to reduction in rank.

precedents.case_name: Appar Apar Singh v. The State of Punjab Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: reversion from officiating higher post (Class I) to substantive lower post (Class II) after punitive enquiry without proper procedure amounts to reduction in rank violating Article 311
precedents.cited_holding: order of reversion amounted to reduction in rank as enquiry investigated allegations and recommended punishment, without disciplinary proceedings
